title: Wild Swimming in Gower
strapline: Discover hidden coves and tidal pools for unforgettable wild swimming adventures on Gower.
metaTitle: Wild Swimming Gower | Hidden Coves & Pools | Adventure Wales
metaDescription: Explore Gower's stunning coastline with our guide to the best wild swimming spots. Find hidden coves, tidal pools, and expert tips for a safe and exhilarating experience.
heroAlt: Wild swimmer in a secluded cove on the Gower Peninsula, surrounded by rocky cliffs and clear turquoise water.
introduction:
Gower, a designated Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, offers some of the most rewarding wild swimming in Wales. Forget crowded beaches and chlorinated pools; here, you'll find secluded coves, dramatic cliffs, and crystal-clear waters teeming with life. The variety is incredible, from the iconic Blue Pool at Broughton Bay, a challenging tidal plunge pool, to the gentle rock pools of Tor Bay, perfect for families. 

What sets Gower apart is its accessibility and sheer natural beauty. You can easily combine a coastal walk with a refreshing dip, discovering hidden gems along the way. However, Gower's wild swimming isn't without its challenges. Tides are a major factor; always check tide times before you go, especially for spots like the Blue Pool and Three Cliffs Bay. Rip currents can also be strong, so it's essential to be a confident swimmer and understand the risks. 

While Gower welcomes all swimmers, it's best suited to those with some experience and a good understanding of open water safety. Families with young children will enjoy the sheltered tidal pools, while more adventurous swimmers can explore the deeper coves and bays. Remember to respect the environment, leave no trace, and enjoy the magic of wild swimming Gower has to offer.

spots.name: Blue Pool (Broughton Bay)
spots.description: The legendary Blue Pool is a deep, saltwater plunge pool carved into the rocks at Broughton Bay. Reaching it requires a scramble over rocks and is only accessible at low tide. The water is surprisingly cold, even in summer, and the pool deepens dramatically, making it suitable for strong swimmers only. Remember to check tide times carefully, as being caught by the incoming tide is dangerous.
spots.bestFor: Experienced open water swimmers seeking a unique challenge.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners, children, anyone with mobility issues.
spots.parking: Broughton Bay car park (SA3 1JF). £5-10 depending on the season. Arrive early on weekends and holidays, as it fills up quickly.
spots.insiderTip: Check Magicseaweed for swell forecast - large swells make access to the Blue Pool dangerous even at low tide.

spots.name: Three Cliffs Bay
spots.description: A classic Gower view, Three Cliffs Bay offers stunning scenery and varied swimming opportunities. The river mouth provides a shallow area for paddling, while more experienced swimmers can venture further out into the bay. Be aware of strong currents, especially around the cliffs and the river mouth. The iconic Pennard Castle overlooks the bay, adding to its dramatic appeal.
spots.bestFor: Confident swimmers comfortable with currents, families looking for paddling spots.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners without supervision, those unsure of tidal currents.
spots.parking: Park at the National Trust car park in Southgate (SA3 2DH). £5 for non-members.
spots.insiderTip: At low tide, walk around to Pobbles Bay for even more secluded swimming spots.

spots.name: Mewslade Bay
spots.description: Mewslade is a quiet, secluded bay backed by impressive cliffs. The walk down to the beach is steep, but the reward is a peaceful swimming experience. The water is generally clear and calm, making it ideal for a relaxing dip. Be aware of the tide, as the beach can be cut off at high tide. There is also a cave on the eastern side of the beach to explore.
spots.bestFor: Those seeking a peaceful and secluded swim.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with mobility issues due to the steep walk.
spots.parking: Limited parking at the top of the lane leading to the beach (SA3 2EW). Get there early, especially during peak season.
spots.insiderTip: Bring a picnic as there are no facilities at Mewslade Bay.

spots.name: Fall Bay
spots.description: Fall Bay is a wild and remote beach accessible only by a long walk across fields. The swim here is rewarding, with clear water and stunning views of Worm's Head. Be prepared for strong winds and waves, as Fall Bay is exposed to the Atlantic. Check the weather forecast carefully before you go. This beach is also popular with seals, so be respectful and keep your distance.
spots.bestFor: Experienced wild swimmers comfortable with challenging conditions.
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners, those seeking an easy access swim.
spots.parking: Park at Rhossili (SA3 1PL) and walk along the coastal path.
spots.insiderTip: The walk to Fall Bay is exposed, so bring plenty of water and sun protection.

spots.name: Brandy Cove
spots.description: Legend says smugglers used this small, sheltered cove. It offers calm waters perfect for a leisurely swim. The beach is pebbly, but the water is clean and clear. It's a great spot for a quick dip after a coastal walk. There's a steep path down to the cove, so wear appropriate footwear.
spots.bestFor: Families, those seeking a calm and sheltered swim.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with limited mobility due to the steep path.
spots.parking: Park at Pwlldu Head car park (SA3 2EB) and walk along the coastal path.
spots.insiderTip: Combine your swim with a walk to Pwlldu Bay for a longer adventure.

spots.name: Pwll Du Bay
spots.description: Pwll Du Bay is a shingle beach accessible by a walk down a valley. The water is generally calm and clear, making it ideal for swimming. It's a popular spot for picnics and relaxing on the beach. There's no lifeguard service, so swim with caution. The walk to the beach is relatively easy, making it suitable for families.
spots.bestFor: Families, those seeking a relatively easy access swim.
spots.parking: Park at Pwlldu Head car park (SA3 2EB) and walk down the valley.
spots.insiderTip: Bring sturdy shoes for the walk down the valley, as the path can be uneven.

spots.name: Caswell Bay
spots.description: A popular surfing beach, Caswell Bay also offers good swimming conditions. The water is generally clean and the beach is lifeguarded during the summer months. There are plenty of facilities nearby, including cafes and shops. It's a great spot for families and those new to wild swimming. Check the surf report before you go.
spots.bestFor: Families, beginners, those seeking a beach with facilities.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those seeking a secluded and peaceful swim.
spots.parking: Caswell Bay car park (SA3 3BS). £1 per hour.
spots.insiderTip: Check the surf report before you go – Caswell can get choppy.

spots.name: Rhossili Bay
spots.description: Rhossili Bay is famous for its stunning views of Worm's Head. The beach is vast and sandy, perfect for a long swim. Be aware of strong currents and waves, especially near Worm's Head. There's a lifeguard service during the summer months. The walk down to the beach is steep, but the views are worth it.
spots.bestFor: Experienced swimmers comfortable with waves and currents.
spots.insiderTip: Walk to the end of the beach towards Worm's Head at low tide for unique rock formations.

spots.name: Tor Bay rock pools
spots.description: At low tide, Tor Bay reveals an extensive network of rock pools, perfect for paddling, exploring marine life, and gentle swimming. Ideal for families with young children. Be mindful of sharp rocks and slippery seaweed. The views across Oxwich Bay are stunning.
spots.bestFor: Families with young children, those seeking a safe and shallow swim.
spots.notSuitableFor: Serious swimmers wanting a long swim.
spots.parking: Tor Bay car park (SA3 1HB). Limited space. Alternatively park at Oxwich and walk.
spots.insiderTip: Bring a bucket and net for exploring the rock pools – but remember to put everything back!

practicalInfo.weather: Gower's coastal weather can be unpredictable. Sea temperatures peak in August, but even then, a wetsuit is recommended. Strong winds and waves can make swimming dangerous, so always check the forecast and tide times before you go. Be aware of sea fog, which can roll in quickly and reduce visibility.
gearChecklist: Wetsuit - Even in summer, the water can be cold.
Swim cap - For warmth and visibility.
Towel - A quick-drying microfibre towel is ideal.
Water shoes - Protect your feet on rocky beaches and in rock pools.
Dry bag - To keep your valuables safe and dry.
Brightly coloured float - For increased visibility in the water.
Sunscreen - Even on cloudy days, the sun can be strong.
Water and snacks - Especially for longer swims.
Whistle - To attract attention in an emergency.

gettingThere.publicTransport: Swansea is the nearest train station. From Swansea, take a bus to various Gower villages. The Gower Explorer bus service connects many of the coastal villages during the summer months.
gettingThere.parkingTips: Parking can be limited, especially during peak season. Arrive early or use park-and-ride services. Be aware of parking restrictions and charges. Consider carpooling to reduce congestion.

practicalInfo.safety: Always swim with a buddy. Check tide times and weather conditions before you go. Be aware of currents and rip tides. Avoid swimming near sewage outfalls or in polluted water. Tell someone where you're going and when you expect to be back. In an emergency, call 999 and ask for the Coastguard. Mobile phone signal can be patchy in some areas of Gower.

faqs.question: Is wild swimming in Gower safe?
faqs.answer: Wild swimming carries inherent risks. Check tide times, weather conditions, and be aware of currents. Never swim alone, and always tell someone your plans. Consider wearing a brightly coloured float for visibility. If in doubt, don't go out!

faqs.question: What is the water temperature in Gower?
faqs.answer: Sea temperatures in Gower typically range from 12-16°C in summer. A wetsuit is recommended, even in August, to stay comfortable for longer swims.

faqs.question: Are there any guided wild swimming tours in Gower?
faqs.answer: While specific 'wild swimming tours' are rare, coasteering companies like Adventure Britain and Gower Activity Centres often include swimming as part of their activities. This is a great way to explore hidden coves with expert guidance.

faqs.question: Where can I hire a wetsuit in Gower?
faqs.answer: PJ's Surf Shop in Llangennith and Oxwich Watersports at Oxwich Bay both offer wetsuit hire. It's advisable to book in advance during peak season.

faqs.question: Are there any lifeguards on Gower beaches?
faqs.answer: Lifeguards are present on popular beaches like Caswell Bay and Rhossili Bay during the summer months (usually from July to September). However, many smaller coves and bays are not lifeguarded, so swim with caution.

faqs.question: Can I swim in the Blue Pool at Broughton Bay?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can swim in the Blue Pool, but it's only accessible at low tide and requires a scramble over rocks. It's a deep pool and suitable for strong swimmers only. Check tide times carefully and be aware of swell conditions.

gearShops.name: PJ's Surf Shop
gearShops.description: A Gower institution, PJ's is the go-to for surf gear, wetsuits, and all things beach-related. They also offer wetsuit hire and expert advice.

gearShops.name: Oxwich Watersports
gearShops.description: Located right on Oxwich Bay, they offer wetsuit and equipment hire, as well as lessons for various watersports.

gearShops.name: Shoreline Surf Shop
gearShops.description: Surf shop located near Mumbles offering equipment sales and rentals. Friendly atmosphere.

postActivitySpots.name: The King Arthur Hotel
postActivitySpots.description: A Gower institution, this hotel and pub is known for its hearty meals, cosy atmosphere, and beautiful gardens. Perfect for a post-swim pint and a filling meal.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Hearty meals, Sunday lunch, real ales

postActivitySpots.name: King's Head
postActivitySpots.description: A classic village pub in Llangennith, popular with surfers and walkers. Expect good food, a friendly atmosphere, and a great selection of local beers.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Post-surf beers, pub classics, live music

postActivitySpots.name: Verdi's
postActivitySpots.address: Knab Rock, Mumbles Rd, Mumbles, Swansea SA3 4EE
postActivitySpots.description: Italian cafe and ice cream parlour with a stunning view overlooking Swansea Bay. Perfect for a post-swim treat or a light lunch.

postActivitySpots.name: Bay Bistro
postActivitySpots.description: Located in Rhossili with panoramic views of the bay. Serves delicious food and drinks, perfect after a swim at Rhossili or Fall Bay.

postActivitySpots.name: The Gower Inn
postActivitySpots.description: A traditional pub nestled in the picturesque Parkmill valley, a short distance from Three Cliffs Bay. Serves home cooked meals and local ales in a friendly atmosphere.

postActivitySpots.name: Beach House Restaurant
postActivitySpots.description: Fine dining restaurant right on Oxwich beach. Serves gourmet meals with stunning views. A more luxurious post-swim treat.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Gourmet food, stunning views, Michelin star

accommodation.name: Three Cliffs Holiday Park
accommodation.description: Camping and caravan site with stunning views of Three Cliffs Bay. Perfect for combining wild swimming with a camping holiday.

accommodation.name: The Gower Hotel
accommodation.description: A comfortable hotel in Bishopston, a short drive from many of Gower's best swimming spots. Offers a range of rooms and a restaurant.

accommodation.name: Oxwich Bay Hotel
accommodation.description: Located right on Oxwich Bay, this hotel offers easy access to the beach and stunning sea views. Perfect for a relaxing swimming getaway.

accommodation.name: Pitton Cross Camping
accommodation.description: A family-run campsite near Rhossili Bay, offering a peaceful base for exploring the west of Gower.

accommodation.name: Oldwalls Gower
accommodation.description: A luxury collection of self-catering cottages and lodges, ideal for families or groups looking for a comfortable base for exploring Gower.

accommodation.name: Shepherd's Hut at Nicholaston Farm
accommodation.description: Quirky and comfortable shepherd's hut accommodation on a working farm near Nicholaston Burrows. A unique way to experience rural Gower.

events.name: Gower Triathlon
events.description: A challenging triathlon featuring a sea swim in Oxwich Bay, followed by a bike ride and run through the Gower Peninsula.

events.name: Gower Walking Festival
events.description: A week-long festival celebrating the Gower Peninsula's stunning coastline and countryside, with guided walks exploring various trails and landmarks, often including coastal swims.

events.name: Mumbles Raft Race
events.description: A fun and wacky raft race in Mumbles, raising money for charity. While not strictly wild swimming, many participants take a dip in the sea.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Gower Activity Centres
discoveredBusinesses.description: Offers a range of outdoor activities, including coasteering, that can be adapted for wild swimming experiences.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: A known operator, offering a good starting point for wild swimming with experienced guides.

discoveredBusinesses.name: PJ's Surf Shop
discoveredBusinesses.description: Provides wetsuit and other gear rentals suitable for wild swimming, located conveniently near Llangennith beach.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Essential for gear in the Llangennith area.

discoveredBusinesses.name: The King Arthur Hotel
discoveredBusinesses.description: A popular pub and restaurant offering post-swim refreshments and meals in a comfortable setting. Central Gower location.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Great place for a post-swim meal and drink.

discoveredBusinesses.name: King's Head
discoveredBusinesses.description: A traditional pub near Llangennith beach, offering a convenient spot for food and drinks after a swim.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: A classic post-swim pub option near a popular beach.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Verdi's
discoveredBusinesses.address: Knab Rock, Mumbles Road, The Mumbles, Swansea
discoveredBusinesses.description: A popular cafe and ice cream parlour in Mumbles, ideal for a post-swim treat with views of the bay.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Perfect for a post-swim treat with stunning views.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Bay Bistro
discoveredBusinesses.description: Located with spectacular views over Rhossili Bay, the Bay Bistro is a great place to refuel after your swim.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Adventure Britain
discoveredBusinesses.address: Suite 5, Business Centre, Navigation Park, Abercynon
discoveredBusinesses.description: Offers various outdoor adventures around Wales; while not specifically wild swimming, their canyoning and gorge walking could be relevant.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: May have some crossover activities suitable for adventurous wild swimmers.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Llangennith Surf School
discoveredBusinesses.description: Primarily a surf school, but they may offer advice or guidance on safe swimming conditions at Llangennith beach.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Good local knowledge of beach conditions.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Oxwich Watersports
discoveredBusinesses.description: Offers SUP, kayaking and coasteering at Oxwich Bay, which may be relevant to wild swimming enthusiasts.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Quest Adventure
discoveredBusinesses.address: Unit 5, Parc Y Werin, Margam, Port Talbot
discoveredBusinesses.description: Offers coasteering and multi-activities around South Wales which could be adapted for wild swimming.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Rip N Rock
discoveredBusinesses.description: Offers Coasteering and surfing adventures around the Gower coast.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Three Cliffs Bay
discoveredBusinesses.description: A stunning bay known for its iconic three cliffs, sandy beach, and opportunities for wild swimming.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: A very popular spot. Be aware of currents and tides.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Rhossili Bay
discoveredBusinesses.description: A wide, sandy bay famous for its dramatic coastline and the wreck of the Helvetia, offering good wild swimming conditions.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Award winning beach, exposed to the Atlantic

discoveredBusinesses.name: Port Eynon Beach
discoveredBusinesses.description: A popular, sheltered beach in Port Eynon village, known for its calm waters suitable for beginner wild swimmers.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Bracelet Bay
discoveredBusinesses.description: A small, rocky bay near Mumbles known for its clear waters and rock pools, suitable for a quick swim.
discoveredBusinesses.notes: Nice cove at the Mumbles Headland.

discoveredBusinesses.name: Langland Bay
discoveredBusinesses.description: A sandy beach with beach huts, popular for swimming and sunbathing.
